thread.title: Market overview: US personal consumption expenditure rises more than forecast in June
thread.title_full: Market overview: US personal consumption expenditure rises more than forecast in June

title: Market overview: US personal consumption expenditure rises more than forecast in June
text:
757.00 +8.5000 
LONDON (ShareCast) - (ShareCast News) - 1330: US personal consumption expenditure rose 1.3% year-on-year in June, above expectations for a 1.2% increase. Personal (LSE: PGH.L - news ) spending rose 0.2%, as expected, while personal income climbed 0.4% to beat forecasts for a 0.3% gain. 1216: The FTSE 100 remains in the red as weak Chinese manufacturing data and lower oil prices sent mining stocks lower. "Having seen a modest bounce last week the mining sector has taken a distinct turn for the worse today, with big names under heavy pressure thanks to the dire news from China. Last week saw the FTSE 100 comfortably outpace its rivals, but reality has struck back today as the raw materials index looks to make fresh lows for the year. US PMI numbers this afternoon should provide," said Chris Beauchamp, senior market analyst at IG (LSE: IGG.L - news ) . 
1100: Greece's economic sentiment index dropped to 81.3 in July from 90.7 month earlier, according to the Institute for Economic and Industrial Research. It marked the lowest reading since October 2012, signalling that concerns for the debt-ridden nation have shown little signs of easing. 
0930: UK manufacturing activity growth accelerated in July, according to data from Markit (NasdaqGS: MRKT - news ) . The PMI (Other OTC: PMIR - news ) rose to 51.9 from 51.4 in June, ahead of forecasts for a reading of 51.5. A reading above 50 signals expansion. 
0900: The FTSE 100 has opened in the red following disappointing US and Chinese data. The US saw poor wage growth and consumer sentiment while Chinese stocks slumped on two weak manufacturing reports. A gauge of miners saw shares decline as copper and oil prices took a hit from weak Chinese and US data. Rio Tinto (LSE: RIO.L - news ) , BHP Billiton (NYSE: BBL - news ) and Randgold Resources slumped. HSBC dominated the headlines after saying first half profits were up by 10%, beating analysis' expectations. The bank's shares rose as it said earnings were driven by a strong performance in Asia. 
CRH (NYSE: CRH - news ) dropped as it announced it has reached an agreement to acquire certain assets from Lafarge (EUREX: 504482.EX - news ) -Holcim for a total enterprise value of â‚¬6.5bn.
